Award.AwardTitle: Systematics and Biogeography of the Family Cicadidae Worldwide: Subsampling the Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Tree of Life project has made substantial contributions to establishing the major branches of the tree of life dating back hundreds of millions of years; this project will focus on the most recent branches. The major goal of the current proposal is to reconstruct and interpret the evolution of the family Cicadidae worldwide as a model for the origin and transcontinental spread of insect biodiversity over the last 65 million years. Most of the plants and animals populating the earth today arose during this era. Genetic data will be used to test five hypotheses concerning the timing and diversification of this remarkable group of more than 3000 insect species. To accomplish this new molecular and analytical tools for genealogical tree building, biogeography and speciation/extinction studies will be incorporated. Fossil and geological calibrations will be applied to groups that no one has previously attempted to date. Cicadas have natural advantages because they are distributed worldwide and their natural history creates strong genetic/geographic patterns.

In the course of our research a new generation of systematists will be trained and trees, maps, keys, photographs, and databases will be created and made available through the worldwide web. A strong international team of researchers and collaborators with complementary expertise in natural history, acoustic analyses, morphological taxonomy, and molecular systematics as well as detailed knowledge of local biogeographic regions has been assembled. The phylogenies produced will help systematists to group undescribed species and genera for which morphological characters are elusive or contradictory. New biodiversity is guaranteed to be discovered. Higher-level taxonomy that has been confused for more than 100 years will be re-evaluated in light of new molecular and morphological data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview. The motivation for our research was the imminent threat of disappearance of valuable global biodiversity. Our scientific goals were to understand how biodiversity arises, how it is shaped by landscape and climate change, and how it spreads throughout the world. We also sought to understand how biodiversity is maintained when lineages encounter other organisms, climates, and biomes. Cicadas have important advantages that facilitated this work (Fig. 1). Specific goals were to 1) reconstruct and interpret the evolutionary history/biogeography of cicadas worldwide as a model for the origin, spread and maintenance of biodiversity, 2) incorporate new analytical tools for generating and analyzing massive amounts of genetic data, 3) use our evolutionary trees as a framework to revise the taxonomy of the family Cicadidae, 4) revise cicada genera, especially intercontinental genera that are likely to be related, 5) expand our website to include information useful to both scientists and the general public, and 6) train new scientists.

Results. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of the Family Cicadidae using five carefully selected genes (131 selected species) and traditional sequencing methods. Later in the project when new techniques became available for efficiently sequencing large sections of the genome, we incorporated this technology to include 429 genes, 99 selected taxa (Fig 2). We found strong support for three traditional cicada subfamilies. We also found support for a new subfamily consisting of deeply diverging African taxa—the small size of this subfamily suggests that it is a remnant of a larger group. We found that the sister group to all other Family Cicadidae subfamilies is a largely new world clade and that many species were misplaced (Fig 2, colors out of place). We studied contact zones between species and found that gene exchange was common among taxa that had diverged from each other less than two to four million years ago.

Intellectual Merit.  When constructing our evolutionary trees we explored how properties of the DNA data influence the calculation of times of branching events on the tree. We demonstrated that age estimates of deeper branch-points can be inflated when fast evolving genes are used.  We showed that results are strongly dependent on the particular species sampled and on the statistical model with which the tree is built. Our work also demonstrated that taxa arise through geographic and ecological isolation and are shaped by landscapes and climates, e.g, the aridification of the southern hemisphere. Diversification largely took place within continents over millions of years followed by later long distance invasion of new areas.  Within geographic regions, species distributions expanded and contracted during the climatic swings of the last 35 million years. Our work demonstrated the need for combination of molecular genetic, morphological, and ecological studies to recognize species.  We revised the subfamily, tribal and generic classification of cicadas that had been confused for hundreds of years. Practical, stable taxonomies that reflect evolutionary relationships are necessary for long term and meaningful information storage and retrieval. Later in our work we added pilot studies of the bacterial endosymbionts of cicadas, especially those that supply their essential amino acids and vitamins.  It is now increasingly realized that organisms are made up of communities of microbes and multicellular hosts and that they must be studied as a unit to gain a complete understanding.
